overview: Luke presents the most complete account of Jesus' life, emphasizing His compassion for outcasts, women, and the poor. Written by a physician for a Gentile audience, it shows Jesus as the Savior of all people.

verses.text: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.
Fear not, for behold, I bring you good news of great joy that will be for all the people. For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.
But I say to you who hear, Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, bless those who curse you, pray for those who abuse you.
And Jesus said, 'Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.'

passages.title: The Nativity
passages.summary: The familiar Christmas story—Jesus born in Bethlehem, laid in a manger, announced to shepherds by angels.

passages.title: The Prodigal Son
passages.summary: Jesus' most famous parable about a rebellious son who returns home and a father who runs to embrace him.

passages.title: The Road to Emmaus
passages.summary: The risen Jesus walks with two disciples, explaining how all Scripture points to Him. Their hearts burn within them.

facts.text: Luke is the longest book in the New Testament and, with Acts, comprises about 28% of the New Testament.
Luke was a physician and Paul's traveling companion—the only Gentile author of a biblical book.
Only Luke records the parables of the Good Samaritan, Prodigal Son, and Rich Man and Lazarus.
Luke emphasizes prayer more than other Gospels, showing Jesus praying at every major moment of His ministry.

figures.name: Jesus
figures.description: The compassionate Savior who seeks the lost, welcomes outcasts, and dies praying for His enemies' forgiveness.

figures.name: Mary
figures.description: Jesus' mother, whose song of praise (the Magnificat) celebrates God's care for the humble and hungry.

figures.name: Luke
figures.description: A physician and careful historian who investigated everything and wrote an orderly account for Theophilus.
